reviewText:
A sequel that seems to improve from the original in every way.

Pros:
- Fantastic level design. Features an outside world that can lead to dungeons, and then dungeons that can connect to other dungeons. It makes the world feel interconnected and organic.
- Clever puzzles. The majority of the puzzles in the game are very mind-bending while also being reasonable enough to solve on your own.
- Improved Combat. The enemy AI isn't perfect, but it's pretty damn good. Enemys will often move try to pin you down, dodge, and even flee. Also, if you're a wizard-lover like me, you'll greatly appreciate the improvements to the spell system, and the skill tree system as a whole.
- VARIETY. This game does a fantastic job of making the world varied enough to keep it fresh while also making it consistant enough to make the world feel connected. Just when you start getting sick of an enemy type or a weapon that you have. the game will throw in something new. Even the puzzles have a decent amount of variety to them with some being reflex-based, being observent of your surroundings, thinking outside the box, and even cracking codes!

Cons (I'm gonna be honest, these are pretty nitpicky):
- While the inclusion of guns is nice, I feel as though they were a bit of a missed opportunity. I came across maybe a total of 3 or 4 firearms on my 1st playthrough, and for the often pitiful damage they do they aren't worth it for the amount of times they seem to malfunction and backfire. There is a firearm that's good, but you'll hardly use it out of fear of wasting the very small amount of ammo it has. Hopefully, they'll be buffed for Grimrock 3. *crossing every finger I got*
- 2 or 3 puzzles in the game felt a bit lazy or too ambiguous, but they're greatly overshadowed by the amount of good puzzles in the game.
- Legend of Grimrock 3 hasn't been made yet.

10/10, Even if you're not a fan of dungeon crawlers, after this game you will be, take it from me, a guy who's never played a dungeon crawler before this one.

reviewText:
Legend of Grimrock 2 will surprise you no matter whether you're fresh off the back of LoG1, are experienced with this style of game from the past, or are completely new to it entirely.

The game is a ridiculously huge improvement from the first -- with a rich open world with copious amounts of surprises and secrets that will have you scanning every wall for those precious buttons, cracking codes scrawled on notes by long-dead adventurers, or chasing pesky leprochaun-like tricksters across the world while grabbing armfuls of hidden goodies along the way. Heck, it may even throw the occasional jump-scare to keep you on your toes if you find yourself fully relaxed and enveloped, like I was. Nope, I wasn't expecting that thing to jump at me, or to be ambushed during a nap.

Make your adventure-squad and set-sail for puzzling fun. When you need a break, take on an impressive beastiary with swords, shields and spells. A lot of the old cast have returned - as have new ones. Combat can still be cheesed like before at times, though the game will throw trump cards at you if you rely too heavily on it - and there's some pretty nasty boss-battles in store to boot.

Three out of two thumbs up for this relaxing-to-frustrating rollercoaster that'll have you fist-pumping on the completion of every puzzle or after emerging victorious from hard-fought battles.

Loving it!

reviewText:
Legend of Grimrock 2 is a proper sequel that improves on the formula and concept of the original and expands on it while still retaining the feel and gameplay of the predecessor.

The most significant change is to the world. While Grimrock 1 provided you with a dungeon crawler in the truest meaning of the phrase i.e. you were in a dungeon, just a dungeon, from start to finish in a somewhat linear journey through, but that's not true for Grimrock 2.
The world of Grimrock 2 is open to be explored and your adventure within it will be much more non-linear. In this world you will walk much more in open air but don't worry there's enough dungeons to be crawled. The game will not tell you where to go now and instead you are free to explore on your own, provided you are able to defeat the enemies and solve the puzzles that stand in your way.

The puzzles in Grimrock 2 are very well made and range from a simple push the button that clicks, to much more elaborate ones, that could take clues from every corner of the world to solve. Either way the puzzles make sense and are rewarding when solved. Their difficulty isn't too high that it should impede the progress of your adventure but there are also plethora of more advanced puzzles and sneaky secrets to be found and solved if you desire the greatest rewards.

Combat has also changed in comparison to the predecessor. The enemies move faster and react quicker and are in general more varied. There are more weapons (completely new firearms class) and armors to be found. The skill system has also been improved and allows for much more versatility.

Legend of Grimrock 2 just has much more content than the predecessor in almost all areas while it still provides the same experience and more, including some subtle humor.

In conclusion answer these questions:
Are you interested in some old school first person dungeon crawling?
Do you like a world where the lore of it is not handed to you on a silver platter but you are free to find out about it through exploration?
Do you like solving puzzles and finding secrets?

If yes, then I can wholeheartedly recommend Legend of Grimrock 2 to you.

Well, I was not sure if I would enjoy playing this game and I did.

So yes, I recommend this game if you read and know what to expect.

reviewText:
Legend of Grimrock 2 is a solid iteration of the first game, offering largely the same kind of gameplay but also boasting a bigger world, more content, and improved game mechanics. While it's not without some flaws, and there are parts of the game that I feel were done better in the original - overall it's still an enjoyable experience.

.

Thanks to a nice mix of dungeons and newly added outdoor areas, environments are a lot more interesting and diverse. Characters are more interesting to develop with the revamped skill system, and chargeable special attacks add an extra level of depth to combat. Progression is less linear and you'll often find yourself backtracking to different parts of the world, gaining access to previously inaccessible areas or secrets (though it can also be frustrating when you don't know where to go and wander into a higher-level area).

On the other hand, I found dungeon design to be somewhat weaker - most fun and memorable battles I've experienced were during boss encounters where there's more open space, cover, and bigger and more interesting enemy combinations. Less can be said about normal dungeon areas, which often put you into narrow corridors or otherwise linear paths or even dead ends. This leaves little to no room for strategy, often causing fights to boil down to attack with all characters

reviewText:
This is the best game I played in a long time.

Great setting:
Huge game world
Great puzzles, some harder than others and with occasions of really getting stuck
Scary dungeons with the possibility of certain death around each corner
Large open outdoor spaces, which can make you feel quite lost, especially in the first half of the game
Interesting races, classes and battle system
Beautiful and diverse scenery

Whenever you get stuck at a puzzle there are enough side tracks to venture on until you get the epiphany that you need (for me, those often come after closing the game).
Only puzzle solved feels like a victory, even if it was just a small one.

My only negative experience with the game was its ending. Without spoiling, I can only say it lacked both originality and good playing experience.

But do not let that prospect spoil the rest of the Grimrock experience, because hours and hours of thrilling gameplay lie ahead!

reviewText:
This game is a worthy sequel to its predecessor. It is not linked story-wise to the first game, so don't worry if you haven't played the first one. It offers an immersive world filled with adventure and mystery, and lots of things to do. This is a game that truly respects the player's intellect, and the puzzles and secrets in this game are many and challenging. This game requires skill just as much as it requires planning ahead and problem solving - which makes it an awesome adventure game.

My only complaint is that you aren't told what all the key items are, so you could find yourself dropping a key item to clean up some inventory space, only to realize later that you need it, and it is now lost in this huge world.

That being said, the immersive world you're in, the beautiful scenery and monsters, the challenging gameplay and the amout of choice you're given makes this game a true dungeon-crawling masterpiece.

reviewText:
I'm really enjoying this game so far! I'm impressed with the variety of scenery you get exposed to. I don't understand why they didn't show off all the different locals on the store page. The cemetary, the forests, the graveyard, the castle, the crypts, the mines, the streams, etc. It's always something different.

Some new features in this genre: Guns, gloves, walking underwater, smooth movement after the first couple of steps - really great and something I was hoping for.
Discovered you have two sets of weapon loadouts for each character - for example a gun and ammo in one set, and dual weild daggers in the other. NICE

AI: all of the enemies seem to have unique AI and abilities and it's really refreshing to this genre. Some enemies have instant attack to thwart the sidestepping exploit common in this type of game, and some can transition between tiles quickly, or even jump to other tiles. New enemies that can occupy your grid (pack of rats) create new combat scenarios. Combat is generally very challenging, fun and rewarding.
The puzzles so far haven't got me stuck for long because it seems like there's always somewhere else you can go, and that tends to help you figure out what to do. Great design. :)

10/10 this is such a great game - one of the few games I'll play to the end. This game is maybe not for everyone but out of the tens of thousands of games I've played, the Dungeon Master and Grimrock series will be ranked in my top 10 best games list.

I wish the game had a vignette filter (darken screen edges) and a brightness control. It would really make it pop. The textures are quite nice.

reviewText:
I won’t describe the game’s mechanics here as that’s done very well elsewhere (search “Rock Paper Shotgun Grimrock 2” for some well written words on the game). But I will say if you want a game that challenges your lateral thinking as well as your reactions this is a great choice.

But the main story mode in this is really very engaging. If you think you’re stuck during the game then try something else, a different area, perhaps. The only gripe I have is that while playing I occasionally felt some of the puzzles were a little _too_ obscure - occasionally relying on assumptions about the players that may not hold true for all or using out-of-game knowledge (or experiences) that not everyone has. But I found ways around that and others may feel that criticism unfair, I’m sure (I’ve avoiding going into details for the sake of spoiler avoidance).

This games improves on the first game in so many ways. Although I would encourage you to play the original Grimrock there’s no need to do that other than it’s a gentler introduction to this style of 3D square based RPG.

A highly recommended game to challenge brain as well as brawn.

reviewText:
Much better than the first Legend of Grimrock, open world, cool items and actually some good puzzles, even though some really bug me. The bosses might be a little bit easier in some places, but you still have a lot of challenge as you need balance using items, skills and managing who is in the front row taking the damage and movement is also key in this one as some enemies have many different kind of attacks that you have to dodge.

Just after few hours of playing the game world opens up so that you have multiple dungeons to explore, notes for hidden treasures and there are even some cool traps, like items that you can pick up just out in the open and then be teleported to a dungeon where you are surrounded by enemies.

Some bad things about the game might be that some builds are useless when compared to others so the character customization is kinda bogged down and there seems to be very little story or interesting characters, so I would not suggest this for people who like a story driven rpg like maybe dragon age or gothic 2, witcher and such.

reviewText:
A very good RPG, kind of in the same vein as Wizardry 8 but not as amazing as that game. You might also say it's like if Might and Magic X was good. The exploration is by far Grimrock 2's strongest point, with a sprawling open-ended world to explore and tons of secrets to find. It can be tense too, as you come to expect horrible things to happen when picking up items, etc. Multiple times I got jumpscared by unexpected enemies. The graphics are even pretty great, especially for an indie studio. Character building and progression isn't bad, though there's some useless skills and it starts to not matter what you level towards the end. Music is great on the menu and in boss battles, but nonexistent otherwise. It works for Myst and Demon's Souls, but I would've preferred some more traditional music to the ambience in this case.

The one thing that really threatens to spoil it is the combat system, which is carried over from the previous game where it also was a problem. Positioning determines roughly 90% of your success, or should I say, whether or not you can find four open squares to move around on. People cheesed enemies in Grimrock 1 with squaredancing, and instead of revamping it, the developers just made skillful squaredancing 100% necessary to have any success in combat. There are more nuances in enemy movement to make it interesting, but if you ever get cornered at the end of a hallway, even the god damn mosquitoes will tear your party apart. I don't care if it's old school, It's fundamentally broken, and anyone who stuck up for it after the first game is wrong. It also sucks that you have to click small icons and make complex actions with the mouse while doing all this movement, when even the 90s RPGs allowed you to attack with hotkeys for your characters. However, combat isn't the majority of the game, and in MOST cases it's manageable without much frustration. It's only when they throw enemies at you in cramped hallways that it stops working well. There were a lot of times where I got gameovers and then easily overcame them the next time because now I knew where I could safely fight.

Anyway, whatever, good game overall.

reviewText:
Wow, what a really fun game.

The Legend of Grimrock games are great, though it caters to an audience with a specific taste. If you ever played the old Eye of the Beholder gameboy game or something like it, you'll appreciate this. Grimrock takes the classic dungeon crawl scheme and modernizes it.

This just doesn't mean better graphics and game mechanics though--the developers of this game really thought about these and spent time putting in intricate, yet very solvable puzzles and riddle-like passive narratives into the game. Meaning, you will be challenged, but you will also feel very rewarded when you figure something out. This perfect balance along with some nice, classic RPG elements make for some great fun.

Legend of Grimrock 2 is better than the first, but this is only because of the graphics upgrade and the much more diverse environments you get to explore instead of being cooped up in a tower all day!

On my top games list--a must for lovers of the genre!

reviewText:
pros
-very little hand holding
-story doesn't get in the way, it's just puzzles & dundeon crawling
-there's a level builder, and some of the custom stories are almost as good as the main game
-easy to use on touchscreen

cons
-besides the level editor, there's not alot of actual mods
-story isn't very unique or engaing, and when some people do talk it's just subtitles (not a even dialogue box) with no voice
-Optimization is not good, and while taking rendering settings to low helps, it doesn't fix it entirely. On top of that, dungeons have more dark spots that you can't see into on when you take rendering settings to low, making the game significantly harder w/o a torch.
-I personally wish the u/i was layed out differently, like having the character portraits in the middle rather than the corner, or if the u/i was just more customizable
-can't bind character attacks/spells to a key
-while it's not the point of the game, npc's and towns would have been cool

ultimately it's a fun game with decent value at full price

reviewText:
An improvement over first LoG which was a solid game as well.

+Better visuals
+Improved combat AI (although you can still outflank most monsters if you arent horribly outnumbered)
+Gameplay improvement.Certain monsters can now fly up and down as additional levels were added to dungeons (you can climb up and fall down and even swim in water )

-Open world model.It seemed like a good change of pace at first after the endless series of corridors first LoG offered but i dont think it worked really well in this type of game.Throughout your play you will be given vague clues on puzzles and treasures that you may enounter a few hours later on a totally diffirent level. While puzzle freaks may find it appealing i certainly didnt because they rarely deliver great items.Only on two such occasions i found strikingly better gear and both of them were 2-handed weapons.
-Classes are ok but could be more intresting.
-Characters can now recieve permanent wounds(debuffs) when they take damage that can only be healed by potions and healing crystals.While it was good to see a new mechanic at start, it grew to be an annoyance as i invested more hours into game.Given that fights in LoG 2 became more brutal we certainly didnt need them to be punishing forcing us to either struggle through inventories to brew some more potions or backtrack to nearest crystal of life.
